title: BHP worker unfairly dismissed over sex toy prank
text:
When BHP’s lawyers put to her that a sex toy might be considered by some as an offensive object, Ms Odgers declared, “well, most people have one".

In March the following year, two days after learning that BHP was investigating the airport incident, she appeared in a “selfie” where she stood on a table in the mine’s meal room, unbuttoned her top down to the last two buttons and provocatively bared the top of her breasts in a bra while bending forward with two other colleagues doing the same.

The photo was uploaded to Facebook by another colleague, garnering 33 likes before it was removed.

Ms Odger claimed the photo was “not inappropriate, nor could it be considered offensive; it was just cleavage”.

“It’s not actually showing breast,” she said in cross-examination.

In her unfair dismissal case, Ms Odgers argued BHP’s disciplinary actions were inconsistent and pointed out she was the only one dismissed out of the photo.

She also referenced another female employee who was not disciplined for telling the Cairns Post it was a “sausage fest” at the mine, which Ms Odgers interpreted as meaning people sleeping with each other on site and that it’s a “free for all”.

'Defies belief'

Advertisement

Fair Work commissioner Jennifer Hunt found BHP had a valid reason to dismiss Ms Odgers for breaching company values of respect and integrity, which said employees should not do anything that might be perceived as offensive.

She said Ms Odgers was 49 and “given her age, there is no rational explanation for her immaturity relevant to the two incidents”.

Ms Odgers was “lucky” her colleague had not been offended over the sex toy but she had no regard to the distraction her stunt would cause security or the risk to BHP’s reputation. The commissioner also found Ms Odgers had “misappropriated” the butter knives from BHP.

On the selfie, taking while Ms Odgers was wearing a shirt with a BHP logo, the commissioner questioned “how any of the women in the photo thought it would be a good idea to pose for such a selfie in the workplace defies belief”.

“It is true that the photo depicts less skin than one would typically see at the beach or at a public swimming pool,” she said.

“It is the provocative pose of each of the women, and act of each of them having unbuttoned their shirts down to below the bottom of their bra, each leaning forward that causes discomfort that employees have elected to behave this way in the workplace.”

But given the women kept their bras on, she said an appropriate disciplinary action would have been to give them a first and final warning.

As to BHP's lack of action over an employee telling the media the mine was a “sausage fest”, the commissioner said Ms Odgers' interpretation was “off track”.

“A ‘sausage fest’ means that there is a preponderance of men compared to women. The reference to ‘sausage’ is a colloquialism because men have a penis and hence the correlation to a sausage.”

Nevertheless, she was “deeply troubled” by BHP’s haphazard approach to its “fair play” policy, which said warnings must be given in disciplinary procedures and was an obligation in the company's enterprise agreement.

As a result, she found the dismissal was unjust and unreasonable and ordered BHP pay compensation.
description: The Fair Work Commission has awarded compensation to the female mine worker despite finding her behaviour "defies belief".
